name: Pair & Mob Programming
description: We encourage people sit at the same computer and collaborate on the same code at the same time. This software development approach helps us to share knowledges in a practical way.

name: Test-Driven Development
description: Write a test to describe the next expected behavior. Write the code to implement the expected behavior until the test passes. Refactor the code to make it well structured. In short: use tests to guide the implementation and do not neglect the refactor step. One more thing: create tests to guard against bugs coming back too.

name: Code Reviews
description: Peer review is intended to find mistakes overlooked in software development, improving the overall quality of software. Reviews can be done in various ways such as pair programming or pull request.

name: Ship / Show / Ask
description: A branching strategy that combines the features of Pull Requests with the ability to keep shipping changes. Changes are categorized as either Ship (merge into mainline without review), Show (open a pull request for review, but merge into mainline immediately), or Ask (open a pull request for discussion before merging) -- from https://martinfowler.com/articles/ship-show-ask.html

name: Definition of Production Readiness
description: Support teams that pratices the *you build it, you run it* principle in assessing and preparing the operational readiness of new services.

name: Consumer-Driven Contract Testing
description: Ensures that a provider is compatible with the expectations that the consumer has of it. Could be not viable for some project due to missing binding of reference implementation, [Pact](https://docs.pact.io/)

name: Coding Standard
description: As in eXtreme Programming definition, teams must have common sets of coding practice, allowing to understand code with ease and encouraging collective ownership

name: Domain-Driven Design
description: Domain-driven design (DDD) is the main approach of our software development, helping to support the evolution of our software systems. We leverage strategic DDD to ensure that our architecture remains focused on business capabilities and that we invest the correct effort on different subdomains, this also includes using tactical DDD patterns in our core subdomains.

name: CQRS
description: Command Query Responsibility Segregation is an architectural pattern that enables multiple representation of the same data in different persistent models. It is suited to complex domains and its obligatory for systems bases on event-sourcing.

name: Event Sourcing
description: The event-sourced domain model, also known as event-sourcing, is one of the DDD tactical patterns. When using event-sourcing the state of a business entity is persisted as a sequence of state-changing events. It is suited for complex domains and the main advantages it brings are deep insight into the system's state and behavior, a strongly consistent audit log and advanced optimistic concurrency management.  Applications must use Command Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) to implement queries to reconstruct the state of the business entities.

name: Event Storming
description: Event storming is a technique for exploring complex domains and the interaction between business actors. We run event storming sessions every time we need to re-align our vision and understandings, to find new hotspots or to discover unexplored parts of our business domain.

name: Clean Architecture
description: AKA Hexagonal Architecture, AKA Onion Architecture. Though these definitions vary somewhat in their details, they are very similar. They all have the same objective, which is the separation of concerns.

name: Lightweight Approach to RFCs/ADRs
description: We use simple standardized templates across many teams as well as version control to capture RfCs (infrastructure) and ADRs (architecture) -- https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/techniques/lightweight-approach-to-rfcs

name: GitOps
description: We currently use with success the *push* based approach for infrastructure deployments. We tried the *pull* based approach to handle applicative deployments but we discovered that for our needs, complexities outweight benefits
